comment.author: 73368734@N00
comment._content: Shouldn't that be "single _masted_ vessel", as in having one mast?  All vessels have only one "master", the ship's captain.  The vessel's mainmast appears to be missing, leaving only the mizzen.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: I agree with the curator's comment at the persistent URL that this shipo is a coal loader, therefore it is unlikely to any longer  be a passenger vessel.

comment.author: 27162331@N02
comment._content: it does appear to have been loaded with coal at the time of this photo but this ship had previously been a navy ship, notice the gun deck port hole covers have cut-outs for the cannons...

comment.author: 97381978@N00
comment._content: It is probably a former frigate hulked for use as a fuelling jetty. HMS Warrior, now preserved at Portsmouth, UK, only survived to today because she remained in use as an oiling jetty until her historical value was recognised and she was rescued. Please add to: Naval History

comment.author: 37832664@N02
comment._content: nice boat

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Why would a passenger vessel have all those cannon ports ?

comment.author: 97381978@N00
comment._content:
See my comment about this probably being a frigate which has been hulked.
Many merchant ships had painted gunports to deter pirates but these are clearly real gunports and the lids even have circular cut-outs to accommodate the gun muzzles.
From this I conclude it is a former frigate or former East Indiaman. East Indiamen were armed.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: EUREKA! She is a VERY OLD ship, HMS NELSON (1814) - short history en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Nelson_(1814) Identified from this Hall photo (ANMM) - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/6819391298/] The figurehead (see Persistent URL at mega zoom) is now in the Australian National Maritime Museum - emuseum.anmm.gov.au/code/emuseum.asp?style=browse&cur... [That only took four years!]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: 1929 fuller history of the ship - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/69519134 . From this it seems she was in Sydney from 1901-1908 near Cremorne.
